posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked:
So our elevator has free range going up and down using the D-pad, our coral arm has two preset position which are intake position (B) and outtake position (A). Intake coral is (Y) and outtake coral is (X).

What we do is lift the elevator to L3 and it holds position fine using ‘stopElevator’ which just runs the Elevator motor at .01.

The problem is that once we are ready to outtake and score, the elevator drops immediately after ANY of the coral bindings (A,B,X,Y) are pushed.

EXTRA NOTE: when the elevator is at zero which is at the bottom, the elevator is forcing itself into the chassis when coral bindings are pressed.

GitHub Link to Code- GitHub - c4psaic1n/geodecode: 8757 GEODEBOTS code

We are meeting tonight at 5:30p-8:30p ET so would be open to a zoom call for assistance

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Do the commands bound to those buttons have the elevator as a subsystem requirement?  Remember that only one command can use a subsystem at a time.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: I just looked at it. Do you mean adding the boolean to say isElevator moving = true\false thing?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
No.  I mean you may want/need to split your coral subsystem into two subsystems, because running a command that uses the intake motor will, with your current architecture, interrupt any command that is using the elevator motor, since they’re part of the same subsystem.

If there’s eventually a “commands library v3” it’d probably be a good idea to rename “subsystem” to “resource” to better communicate what the class represents.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: So we should separate CoralSubsystem and create a separate ElevatorSubsystem?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Yes; in general anything that is an independently-operating chunk of your robot should be its own subsystem.

The subsystem class is a “mutex” that constrains concurrent access to resources.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nafi
posts.cooked: Can you not keep your elevator motors in brake mode? That should hold the elevator up whilst your coral commands are being ran, or at the very least there should only be slight force downwards from gravity.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Brake mode only introduces viscous drag; it provides zero holding force.  The correct way to keep an elevator stationary is with a feedforward + feedback controller.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: It IS on brake mode and we have two extra boxes on it 5:1 and 4:1.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Another option is to always do “hold position” where something like a profiled PID controller is actively working to maintain the position.  You can then ensure this runs as part of execute() for every command (or run position control on the motor controller).  This assumes you always want to hold at some position and don’t need the elevator to do anything else, which is fairly typical.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: We do something similar, but where periodic() is constantly holding the elevator (with the caveat that we also have some climbing behavior on our elevator that doesn’t; our 2023 code is much simpler).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
I didn’t spot anything in the code you posted, and using periodic() is a solid approach.  I’m guessing something in your code is running a command (climb related?) that is setting the motor to zero, but it’s hard to say without more time (my main constraint), access to the full source, and maybe the robot.

Graphing the telemetry in something like AdvantageScope, or sometimes even a little printing, can help you see what is going on.  Or, simulation, if you are doing that.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: Yeah we just went back to REVs original code and did step by step and found out its whenever we change setpoints
